“As a fishing/sporting camp, we lost 25% of our season right off the top. We were allowed to reopen in June, but after canceling everyone, we had a hard time filling it back in." 5/

This is only one of the ways that the Lower Drug Costs Now Act would fight rising drug prices. The bill also gives Medicare Part D the power to negotiate directly with drug companies, and those lower prices would also be available to Americans with private insurance. (5/5)

The AIM price is a volume-weighted average of the price of prescription drugs in Australia, Canada, France, Germany, Japan, & the United Kingdom. If there's no AIM price for a certain drug, the max in the United States would be capped at 85% of the avg. manufacturer price. (4/5)

For drug price negotiations between PBMs and big pharmaceutical companies in the United States, the Lower Drug Costs Now Act would set the max price at 120% of the average international market, or AIM price. (3/5)

Why does it matter what someone pays for a prescription drug in another country?

The Lower Drug Costs Now Act, which I cosponsored and voted to pass, would set max prices for U.S. drugs based on average prices in comparable countries. (2/5)

U.S. drug prices are nearly 4 times higher than the average prices in similar nations like Australia & Germany. Even accounting for rebates, Americans pay more than their counterparts overseas – you can visit http://www.46brooklyn.com/ to see comparisons for your medication. (1/5)

These are not hard questions, and the CJCS and Secretary of Defense have already responded to my similar questions.

This is about the integrity of our institutions, the bones that hold up our democracy.

I sincerely hope @DHS_Wolf comes back to us with a response in short order.

It is reasonable to ask DHS in general, and Acting Secretary Wolf specifically, to reassure the American public that they will abide by their responsibility to protect the homeland –– not any one president –– in the days leading up to and following the election.

Since June, DHS has inserted federal troops into U.S. cities without consent from local officials, used unmarked security forces operating under an opaque chain of command, and have politicized intelligence on Russian efforts to influence our political process.

I asked these questions in the first place because, in recent months, DHS has demonstrated their willingness to act as a political entity, rather than an apolitical law enforcement and intelligence organization:

A month ago, I submitted questions to @DHS_Wolf, asking him to commit to uphold DHS’ apolitical role in the upcoming election.

DHS tells us they may not respond until after the election –– defeating the purpose of such questions & ignoring their urgency. https://slotkin.house.gov/media/press-releases/slotkin-submits-formal-questions-dhs-apolitical-role-secretary-chad-wolf-after

That is why I sent a letter to @DNI_Ratcliffe asking him & career intel officials to brief Congress on the full spectrum of election threats, and for him to provide public testimony, so that the American people can understand his analysis: https://slotkin.house.gov/media/press-releases/slotkin-presses-dni-ratcliffe-ongoing-politicization-intelligence-president-s

The DNI's announcement on Iran and Russia confirms what has long been apparent. Foreign actors remain persistent and effective in sowing distrust and division.

Because the threat of misinformation and division is so great, clarity and transparency on these threats is critical.

In addition to this mom being separated from her daughters, we saw dozens of women and children in holding cells, sleeping side by side on benches and cement floors with no room to walk between their bodies, no windows, and no place for the children to play.

Her older daughter was withdrawn, and we learned that she was having difficulty with the reunion. 

It was easy to see how conflicted the little girl was and her struggle to reconcile the attachment she had formed to her foster family.

This mom described how much of a toll being separated from her little girls had on her, but she didn’t have to. 

We could see it in her face, in her tears, and in the way she and her younger daughter clung to each other.

She walked across the border with her daughters and requested asylum.  Her daughters were taken from her and placed in foster care.

No reason was given for this separation.

I feel the need to share this story with you all again tonight. 

When I went to our southern border last February, I met with a mother who was just reunited with her children the night before. 

(Thread)
